 Madame Assitan (3ème femme debout de la gauche vers la droite dans la photo) est une grande vendeuse de lait  dans le village de Massalawere et ses environnants. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 50 litres de lait. La revente se fait au comptant  et souvent à crédit à une clientèle mixte.
 Madame Assitan espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen  de  18 000 FCFA avec ce prêt, qui sera utilisé pour  des frais de scolarisation de ses enfants et augmenter également  son fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
The ten women of the Baara group all live in polygamous families. They average 37 years old with 4 children each. They all live in the village called Massalawere, in the Ségou region (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met through neighbors, relatives, marriage, and their businesses in the village.

They sell milk, grains, prepared food, clothing and cosmetics. With the goal of increasing their business, the group members decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso, and are on their 1st solidarity loan cycle. 

Assitan (the woman standing 3rd from the left in the photo) is a well-known milk vendor in the village of Massalawere and the surrounding areas. She plans on using her loan to buy 50 liters of milk. She sells her milk to male and female customers for cash and frequently on credit. Assitan hopes that this loan will enable her to earn an average monthly income of 18,000 CFA Francs, which will be used to pay the schooling fees for her children and to bolster her capital.

loans.use: to buy milk.

loans.name: Cyrillah

texts.en:
Cyrillah is a 30-year-old married woman. She has two children. She describes herself as determined. She operates a tailoring machine where she makes curtains. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located in a vibrant place and her primary customers are of all types. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of funds. 

She will use the KES 100,000 loan to buy materials to make curtains and also buy a sewing machine. Her business goal is to have a boutique within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will build a permanent house. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM. Her previous loan was repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to open a new shop.

loans.use: to buy materials to make curtains and a sewing machine.

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Ly is 50 years old and divorced with three children. She lives with her family in a small house in Ho Chi Minh City. She has been running a karaoke service and a small beauty shop for earning a living. She started her business fourteen years ago. 

She intends to take a loan to gradually expand her business by upgrading her karaoke rooms for better serving her customers. 

She hopes her business runs smoothly and will help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to upgrade her karaoke rooms for better serving her customers.

loans.name: Serine

texts.en:
Serine is a beautiful lady of 27 years. She lives in Stapanavan city in Lori region. She has graduated from Vanadzor State Pedagogical Institute, the faculty of Pedagogy and Psychology. She is not married and she is engaged in pedagogy fully. She works with great love, care and patience towards the children. At this moment she works at the Vanadzor Special School of aggressive children as a leading special pedagogue. Serine also gives private paid courses of Armenian Language and Literature at her home. Serine lives with her parents and smaller sister. Her father is a constructor. Her mother and sister are unemployed.

Sereine is asking for a loan of 400,000 Armenian Drams since she wants to buy a computer and some new literature connected with her work at the Special School.

loans.use: to buy a computer and some new literature connected with her work at the Special School.

loans.name: Hillary

texts.en:
Hillary is a 32-year-old married man. He has 4 children with ages ranging from 3 years to 12 years. 

He describes himself as determined. He operates a carpentry business where he makes furniture for sale. He has been involved in this business for 5 years. His business is located in an urban area and his primary customers are small scale. He describes his biggest business challenge to be scarcity of indigenous trees for timber. 

He will use the KES 25,000 loan to buy more stock of timber for making furniture. His business goal is to excel within 5 years. He will use the anticipated profits to build a permanent home.

loans.use: to buy more stock of timber for making furniture

loans.name: Priscilla

texts.en:
This is Priscilla, a 47-year-old resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is single and she is working hard to continually provide income for her family's everyday expenses.

Priscilla operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5 PHP amount of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

She is requesting a 11,000 PHP loan to help her continue operating her business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Priscilla dreams that her business will grow bigger and hopes that her adopted child will finish his studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Djeyhun

texts.en:
Djeyhun is 26 years old, single and lives with his parents in Baku region. His father was sick for many years and Djeyhun supports all the needs of the family. Therefore for that reason he couldn’t get married. Today he is engaged and in the near future wants to have a family. 

Djeyhun is in the taxi driver business. He transports passengers between various areas of Baku region. Today Djeyhun wants to repair his car. For this reason he has applied to Komak company. Djeyhun needs a loan of an amount of 800 Azerbaijan New Manat- AZN. 

He is very thankful to the Kiva organization and all lenders for their help.

loans.use: to repair his car.

loans.name: Nyakaina Women Group

texts.en:
Jazzila is a twenty-eight-year-old married woman with four children, of which three go to school. 

She has been selling clothes for four years, working seven days a week and eight hours a day in a rural area, and she also does farming as additional income. 

Jazzila started this business for self-sustainability and wants money to buy clothes. Jazzila hopes to expand her business and educate her children. However, seasonality changes are a challenge. Jazzila is a hardworking woman.

loans.use: to pay for clothes to sell.

loans.name: Armenuhi

texts.en:
Armenuhi is from Berdavan village. She lives together with her husband and 22-year-old daughter. Arenuhi's son is a migrant worker in a neighboring country and works hard to support his family financially.

Armenuhi's husband provides construction service to locals. However, the main income of the family comes from agriculture. The family runs a farm which includes livestock and a plot of land. Armenuhi and her husband sell the gathered agricultural harvest locally. 

Now, by applying for this loan, Armenuhi asks for financial support to be able to enlarge her farm. She plans to purchase four calves and forage for the livestock so as to make her farm richer with hopes of having more income from it. 

Armenuhi waits for your support.

loans.use: to pay for four calves and forage for the livestock

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is a 29-year-old married woman. She has one child. She describes herself as determined and confident. She operates a M-pesa business where she offers mobile phone based money transfer services. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her business is located in a urban area and her primary customers are small scale. 

She will use the KES 30,000 loan to buy a photocopier machine to offer photocopying services to enable her earn more income. Her business goal is to excel within five years. She hopes that in the future, her life will be different. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM. Her previous loan of KES 20,000 was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy a photocopier machine to offer photocopying services.

loans.name: Julio César

texts.es:
Julio es un hombre de 35 años de edad, trabajador y con una visión de negocio que lo ha impulsado a crear su propia empresa; es contratista de construcción y, desde hace 10 años creó su propia empresa, la cual inició en Barranquilla y, luego se trasladó a la ciudad donde actualmente lleva 3 años en funcionamiento. Actualmente cuenta con el apoyo de 4 empleados, trabajan todos los días de 7 am a 6 pm y ha logrado así, generar ingresos para solventa sus gastos familiares.
El crédito que solicita será invertido en la compra de un computador y un software, con lo que podrá agilizar la labor y podrá llevar una contabilidad organizada para su negocio.
Julio manifiesta que su mayor anhelo es fortalecer y estructurar muy bien su proyecto productivo, generar oportunidades de empleo y ampliar su mercado objetivo, así tendrá la posibilidad de mejorar las condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Julio is a 35 year-old man and a hard worker with a business vision that inspired him to create his own company. He is a construction contractor and established his own business ten years ago in Barranquilla. He later moved to the city where he has been in operation for three years. 

He currently has the support of four employees who work every day from 7 a.m. until 6 p.m.  His business has generated enough income to cover his family's expenses.  The loan he is requesting will be used to invest in the purchase of a computer and software which will allow him to speed up the work and to organize the business's accounting.  Julio states that his greatest desire is to strengthen and structure his business, generate employment opportunities, and expand his target market. He will then be able to improve his living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a computer and software.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more tough-light, body cream, grease, and artificial hair to attract her customers.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy clothes, shoes and groceries for resale

loans.name: Nyetaa Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre  femmes du groupe Nyetaa vivent toutes dans des familles polygamiques. Elles ont en moyenne 39 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le village de Massalawere dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative de la Républiques du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté, mariage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu dans le village. Elles font le petit commerce, de la farine, de restauration d’habillement et de cosmétique. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er  cycle du prêt solidaire.
 Madame Awa (dernière femme debout de la droite vers la gauche dans la photo) est une grande vendeuse de farine sucrée et pâté  dans le village de Massalawere et ses environnants. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 1 sac de farine de blé pour satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle. La revente se fait au comptant  et souvent à crédit à une clientèle mixte.
 Madame Awa espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen  de 7500 FCFA avec ce prêt, qui sera utilisé pour des frais de scolarisation de ses enfants et augmenter également  son fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
The four women of the group Nyetaa all live in polygamous families and average 39 years of age and three children each. All the women live in the village of Massalawere, in Région de Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know one another through ties of community, kinship, marriage, and their revenue-generating businesses in the village. They work in small-scale commerce involving wheat flour, food service, clothing, and cosmetic products. 

With the goal of increasing their business capital, the group members decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their first solidarity loan cycle. 

Ms. Awa (last woman standing from right to left in the photo) is a major vendor of sugared flour and pâté in and around the village of Massalawere. She intends to use her loan to purchase a sack of wheat flour in order to meet customer demands. Sales are maid to a mixed customer base paying cash and often on credit. 

Ms. Awa hopes to make an average monthly profit of 7,500 francs CFA that will be used to cover her children's schooling costs and also to increase her capital.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour

loans.name: Cordillera Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “CORDILLERA” iniciará el décimo primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Los Andes, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Martha es la Tesorera. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: macramé de mantas, tienda de barrio, venta de alfombras, venta de dulces, venta de salchipapas, venta de calzados.
El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Martha es integrante, ella indica que hace diez años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de una vecina que es socia de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de salchipapa (comida tradicional); da a conocer que este negocio lo emprendió cuando su esposo se internó en un centro  médico y ella tenía que generar recursos económicos, es por ello que sus cuñadas le dieron un pequeño capital con el cual inicio el comercio, posterior a la mejora de su esposo continuo con el negocio que le apoyaba a la familia.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de papas, aceites y salchichas por mayor) que adquirirá en las ferias de la ciudad de El Alto y posteriormente al elaboración lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener a su familia ya que ella es casada y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el área de salud y capacitación que le ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Cordillera” (Mountain Range) is starting its 10th loan cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Los Andes Community Center. This group consists of eight members and is led by a Board of Directors in which Sra. Martha serves as the treasurer. The members of this Communal Bank engage in various businesses such as producing macramé blankets, managing a neighborhood store, selling rugs, selling sweets, selling sausages and potatoes, and selling shoes.

This loan will be used to benefit small businesswomen such as Sra. Martha. She says that she joined Pro Mujer 10 years ago after receiving an invitation from a neighbor who is a member of the organization. At the moment, Martha has a business in which she sells “salchipapas” (a traditional fast food dish that consists of sausages and fried potatoes). She started this business when her husband got admitted into a clinic and she needed to raise some money. For this reason, her sisters-in-law gave her a small amount of capital so that she could start this venture. Later on, after her husband got better, she continued the business in order to support her family.

The loan she is receiving now will be used to increase her capital for buying potatoes, oil, and sausages in bulk. She will acquire her supplies at the fairs in the of El Alto and then use them for preparing the dishes that she sells from her retail space. Working in this manner enables her to generate income for sustaining her family. Martha is married and has two children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, Martha said that she enjoys the health seminars and the training offered by the organization.

loans.use: to buy potatoes, oil, and sausages in bulk.

loans.name: Hakilitoyerela Group

texts.fr:
Les sept femmes du groupe Hakilitoyerela vivent toutes dans des familles polygamiques. Elles ont en moyenne 39 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le village de Daoulabougou dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative de la Républiques du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté, mariage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu dans le village. Elles font le petit commerce d’ustensiles, de grains et de condiments. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 6eme   cycle du prêt solidaire.
 Madame Fatoumata (1ere femme debout de la   gauche vers la droite  dans la photo) est une grande vendeuse d’ustensiles dans le village de Daoulabougou et ses environnants. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter une grande quantité d’ustensiles pour satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle. La vente se fait au comptant  et souvent à crédit à une clientèle majoritairement féminine.
 Madame Fatoumata espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen  de 10000FCFA avec ce prêt, qui sera utilisé pour des frais de scolarisation de ses enfants et augmenter également  son fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
The seven women of the group Hakilitoyerela all live in polygamous families and average 39 years of age and three children each. All the women live in the village of Daoulabougou, in Région de Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know one another through ties of community, kinship, marriage, and their revenue-generating businesses in the village. They work in small-scale commerce involving utensils, grains, and condiments. 

With the goal of increasing their business capital, the group members decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their sixth solidarity loan cycle. 

Ms. Fatoumata (first woman standing from the left in the photo) is a major vendor of utensils in and around the village of Daoulabougou. She intends to use her loan to purchase a large amount of utensils in order to meet customer demands. Sales are made to mostly women customers paying cash and often on credit. 

With this loan, Ms. Fatoumata hopes to make an average monthly profit of 10,000 francs CFA that will be used to cover her children's schooling costs and also to increase her capital.

loans.use: to purchase utensiles

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is a married man. He has 4 children. He describes himself to be focused. 

He operates a tailoring business where he makes men's suits to sell. He has been involved in this business for 15 years. His business is located in a good area for business and his primary customers are male. 

He describes his biggest business challenge to be that a lot of capital is required. He will use the KES 80,000 loan to buy fabric, threads and other materials for making men's suits. His business goal is to open a boutique within 5 years. He hopes that in the future, he will enlarge his business. This is his seventh loan with SMEP DTM. He will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: to buy fabric, threads and other materials for making men's suits

loans.name: Fotemaban Group

texts.fr:
Les sept femmes du groupe Fotemaban vivent toutes dans des familles polygamiques. Elles ont en moyenne 36 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le village de Daoulabougou dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative de la Républiques du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté, mariage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu dans le village. Elles font le petit commerce de fruits et légumes, des grains et de condiment. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 8eme  cycle du prêt solidaire.
 Madame Maïmouna (3eme  femme debout de la gauche vers la droite dans la photo) est une grande vendeuse de fruits et légumes dans le village de Daoulabougou et ses environnants. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter une grande quantité de fruits et légumes pour satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle. La revente se fait au comptant  et souvent à crédit à une clientèle mixte.
 Madame Maïmouna espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen  de  5.500FCFA avec ce prêt, qui sera utilisé pour satisfaire des petits besoins familiaux.
texts.en:
The seven women of the group Fotemaban all live in polygamous families and average 36 years of age and three children each. All the women live in the village of Daoulabougou, in Région de Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know one another through ties of community, kinship, marriage, and their revenue-generating businesses in the village. They work in small-scale commerce involving fruit & vegetables, grains, and condiments. 

With the goal of increasing their business capital, the group members decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their 8th solidarity loan cycle. 

Ms. Maïmouna (the third woman standing from the left in the photo) is a major vendor of fruit & vegetables in and around the village of Daoulabougou. She intends to use her loan to purchase a large amount of fruit & vegetables in order to meet customer demands. Sales are made to a mixed customer base paying cash and often on credit. 

With this loan, Ms. Maïmouna hopes to make an average monthly profit of 5,500 francs CFA that will be used to meet sundry family needs.

loans.use: to purchase fruit & vegetables

loans.name: Siguitemasson Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq  femmes du groupe Siguitemasson vivent toutes dans des familles polygamiques. Elles ont en moyenne 40 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le village de Daoulabougou dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative de la Républiques du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté, mariage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu dans le village. Elles font le petit commerce de la pâte d’arachide, de grains, de restauration et de condiment. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 12ème  cycle du prêt solidaire.
 Madame Satou (1ere femme debout de la droite  vers la gauche dans la photo) est une grande vendeuse de pâte d’arachide dans le village de Daoulabougou et ses environnants. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter une grande quantité de pâte d’arachide pour satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle. La vente se fait au comptant  et souvent à crédit à une clientèle majoritairement féminine.
 Madame Satou espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen  de 19 000FCFA avec ce prêt, qui sera utilisé pour des frais de scolarisation de ses enfants et augmenter également  son fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
The five women of the Siguitemasson group all live in polygamous families. They average 40 years old with 3 children each. They all live in the village of Daoulabougou, in the Ségou region (4th Administrative Region of the Republic of Mali). They met through neighbors, relatives, marriage, and their business activities in the village. 

They sell peanut butter, grains, prepared foods and condiments. With the goal of increasing their business in mind, the members of the group decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso, and are on their 12th solidarity loan cycle. 

Satou (the woman standing on the right in the photo) is a successful peanut butter vendor in the village of Daoulabougou and the surrounding areas. She plans on using her loan to buy a large quantity of peanut butter in order to meet the demands of her customers. She sells her peanut butter for cash or on credit to mostly female customers. 

Satou hopes that the loan will enable her to earn an average monthly income of 19,000 CFA Francs, which will be used to pay schooling fees for her children and to increase her capital.

loans.use: to buy peanuts.

loans.name: Bwizi Networking Group

texts.en:
Rose is a resident of Kyenjojo, Uganda, 32 years old, and a mother of three children. She is a member of a village bank where members guarantee one another for a loan as they do not have security to offer in order to get individual loans. 

She is a hard-working peasant and operates a restaurant. She started this business because there was demand for fast foods in the highly populated town of Kyenjojo. She has dreams of educating her children and turning the business into a large outdoor catering restaurant. Rose has asked for a loan to buy more assets for the restaurant.

loans.use: to buy more assets for the restaurant.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy flour, sugar and cooking fat.

loans.name: Tran

texts.en: Tran, 31, is married and lives in Ho Chi Minh City. She has 2 sons (one is in the picture). She earns a living running a beauty shop. She started this business to cover her expenses and to generate income to cover her family expenses. She is requesting a loan to expand her business by buying more haircare products and accessories to stock her shop. She hopes that this will enable her to attract more customers and that she will be able to increase the turnover of her business. She hopes that through the loan she will be able to expand her business activities and have money to reinvest in her business in the future.

loans.use: to expand her business by buying more haircare products and accessories to stock her shop

loans.name: Neng's Group

texts.en:
Neng, 54, is from a rural village located in the Dambae district of Kampong Cham province. She is widowed with seven children. She has been earning a living through planting cassava for 20 years. The current business earns her about 44,000 KHR per day to meet the family’s needs.
 
Neng has been with VisionFund for seven cycles and completely paid back the past loans, which have helped her better support her family. Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan. As the leader, Neng is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland and to buy piglets to raise. She hopes to earn more income from her current business to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland

loans.name: Sin Bandera Group

texts.es: Grupo formado por tres socios emprendedores de éxito  una de ella es Marlene mujer empresaria que se dedica a la venta de leche y perecederos, estos los comercializa en su domicilio y en el mercado de su localidad, desde hace varios años, ella tiene 42 años es acompañada, el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de leche de vaca por bidones, así también sus perecederos como pipián, tomate, cebolla, chiltoma, chayote, yuca, ayote etc. ella misma atiende su negocio ya que tiene su clientela, Jose tiene 41 años y su negocio es que es agricultor y vende leña y Justa mujer de 41 años y su negocio es la hecha y venta de tamales pisques, tamales rellenos.
texts.en:
This group consists of three successful and enterprising members. One of them is Marlene, a businesswoman who sells milk and perishable goods. She sells her products from her home and at the market in her town. Marlene has been in business for several years. She is 42 years old and married. Her loan will be invested in large cans of milk, as well as perishable goods such as squash, tomatoes, onions, bell peppers, chayote, cassava, gourds, and other items. Marlene manages her business because of her customers.

Jose is 41 years old and works as a farmer. He also sells firewood. Justa is a 41-year-old woman who has a business in which she makes and sells “tamales piques” (tamales that have a bean filling) and “tamales rellenos” (tamales stuffed with various fillings).

loans.use: to buy large cans of milk, as well as perishable goods such as squash, tomatoes, onions, bell peppers, chayote, cassava, gourds, and other items.

loans.name: Nune

texts.en:
Nune lives in Aygehovit village which is in Tavush region. She lives with her husband and two sons (ages 8 and 5 years old). Nune's husband is a manufacturer and receives different orders for making furniture and other wood products. Nune herself takes care of the household and kids. 
She keeps a small but beautiful farm which includes two pigs and 30 chickens as well as cultivates different types of fruits and vegetables. 

As the income that her husband gathers isn't stable and there are many costs to cover in the family, agriculture is very important for Nune. She asks for this loan in order to be able to purchase agricultural machinery for mowing the grass. This is very important for organizing the cultivation process and the loan will be a huge support for this family.

loans.use: to pay for agricultural machinery for mowing the grass.

loans.name: Yuheap Chun's Group

texts.en:
A citizen from a rural village located in the Kampong Cham province’s Choeng Prey district, Yuheap is 42-years-old and married with three children.  For the last 23 years, she has been farming rice and working for others for a fee. With the current business, she can earn about KHR 45,000 per day and can save about KHR 20,000 each day for the future needs.

Yuheap has been a member of VisionFund for one cycle already and she completely paid back the loan, which has enabled her to better support her family.  Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan. As the leader, Yuheap will use her portion to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland. She hopes to grow her rice fruitfully to sell if for a good price to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Cheung Prey district

loans.name: Yoeun Teng's Group

texts.en: Yoeun is 54 years old and a widowed mother blessed with one kid. Currently, rice farming and her occupation as the village chief are the main sources of her family’s income, which generates her about 18,400 KHR (Cambodian riels) per day. This is not the original loan for Yoeun with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). The past loan, which she has fully repaid, has helped her to keep her kid in school until university level. For this loan cycle, she gets a new loan in order to buy a decent motorbike to support her occupation. She hopes that she can reduce the transportation cost that she used to have; thereby, she can use that money to support her kid until graduation instead.

loans.use: To buy a decent motorbike to support her occupation

loans.name: Sophan

texts.en:
Sophan is age 43 and single. She lives in a rural village in the Ponhea Krek district of Kampong Cham province. To make a living, she has been farming rice and working for others for a fee. To supplement the family income, she also sells fish. Having been in this business for 25 years, she is able to earn about 14,000 riels (KHR) per day to support her family. 

Sophan has been with VisionFund one cycle and completely paid back her past loan. Now she is seeking another loan. Sophan is going to use her loan to buy fertilizers for her farmland. She will also use a portion of it to buy a decent motorbike for commuting to work. She hopes to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Sokim

texts.en:
Sokim is 21 years old and single, living with her parents and siblings in Bakan district, Pursat province. She has just graduated from high school and aimed to pursue a university degree. Sokim dreams of becoming a nurse. She is currently attending International University in Phnom Penh for her nursing degree. She is passionate about studying this subject because she hopes to raise her family out of poverty, and at the same time, help village people improve their health.
 
This loan amount will be used to finance the educational fees. Sokim wants to finish her studies and have a better job in the future. She is very happy and thankful for the loan funded via the program like Kiva to enable poor students to pursue a higher level of education and contribute to the future development of Cambodia.

loans.use: to finance the educational fees for her nursing degree.

loans.name: Hamida

texts.en:
Hamida is a 34-year-old married woman. She has two children ages 4 years and 7 years. She describes herself to be God-fearing and loyal. She operates a retail business selling clothes. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located in a marketable place and her primary customers are ladies. 

Hamida describes her biggest business challenge to be price fluctuations. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes for resale. Her business goal is to be a wholesale supplier of clothes within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will save and have a better life. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: buy more stock of clothes

loans.name: Jamil

texts.en: Jamil is a resident of Kyenjojo, Uganda, 34 years old, and a father of three children. He is a hard-working man and operates a restaurant and a meat roasting oven to prepare meat for selling. He started this business because there was demand for fast foods in the highly populated town of Kyenjojo. He has dreams of educating his children and turning the business into a large indoor and outdoor catering restaurant. Jamil wants a loan to buy more goats for meat to roast and sell.

loans.use: to buy more goats for meat to roast and sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more palm oil, rice and cooking seasonings to expand her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy used clothes

loans.name: Libardo

texts.es:
Libardo es un hombre humilde, sencillo y muy trabajador, vive con su esposa y su pequeño hijo de 6 años de edad, por quienes lucha incansablemente para que no les falte nada.
Desde hace muchos años se dedica a trabajar en la explotación minera, pues saca arena de las orillas del río Magdalena y  la comercializa a diferentes obras de construcción del municipio donde reside, de esta forma genera los recursos económicos suficientes para llevar el sustento diario a su hogar.
Con el ánimo de mejorar los ingresos, solicita el apoyo del crédito para fortalecer su negocio, pues con el dinero comprará una canoa con la que podrá introducirse al río para extraer más cantidad del mineral y así tener mayor disponibilidad para cumplir con los pedidos de su clientela, mejorando así los ingresos familiares.
Libardo manifiesta que su mayor anhelo es ampliar su negocio y generar oportunidades de empleo entre los jóvenes del municipio, para así aportar a la economía de la población y mejorar la calidad de vida, tanto de su familia, como la de otras personas que influyan en la labor.
texts.en:
Libardo is a humble, modest, and very hard-working man.  He lives with his wife and their little six year old son.  It is for their son that they work untiringly so that he does not lack for anything.

For many years he has worked in mining.  He takes the sand from the banks of the river Magdalena, and he sells it to different construction works in the municipality where he lives.  This way he generates enough financial resources to bring home the daily sustenance.  

With the intention of improving his income, he is requesting the help of a loan to strengthen his business.  He will use the loan to buy a canoe with which he will be able to get in the river in order to extract a greater quantity of minerals.  This way he will have greater availability in order to fill his customers’ orders.  This way he will be improving the family income.

Libardo says that his biggest desire is to expand his business and to generate employment opportunities for the young people in the municipality.  This way he will contribute to the population’s economy and improve his family’s quality of life as well as that of other people impacted by the work.

loans.use: to buy a canoe.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more fresh fish for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more fish for her business

loans.name: Benson

texts.en:
Benson, a 45-year-old married father of three, lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda where he has been involved in agriculture for 15 years. To meet demand, he also  buys and mills maize, rice and cassava. His main challenge are machine breakdowns.

Benson has requested this loan to buy cassava and maize to mill and sell. His goals are business growth and the education of his children.

loans.use: to buy cassava and maize to mill and sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase soft drinks for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more soft drinks, beer, stout, and white spirit gin for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more flasks, bags milk, sugar, tea bags and drinks for resale.

loans.name: Ledis Margoth

texts.es:
Ledis en su negocio de venta de mercancías,  compra  ropa y productos naturales y da respuesta  a   su clientela en todo lo que le encargan y que ella ofrece a crédito, para que poco a poco, con una frecuencia quincenal le paguen. Desde hace 10 años inició esta actividad de comerciante, cuando se separó de su esposo y debió generar ingresos autónomos para atender  las necesidades de su familia en la cual tiene 2 hijos, en ese momento en edad de estudio. Su meta más importante es adquirir una nueva vivienda  y por eso trabaja con mucho esmero para lograrlo. 
Su mayor desafío es lograr aumentar sus ventas, pero su capital de trabajo no es suficiente para lograrlo; aun así  sus cuentas por cobrar rotan cada 17 días y su rentabilidad sobre las ventas no es menor del 35%. En la actualidad  Ledis está aplicando aun credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará ropa, vitaminas, productos naturales, que están encargados y que son los de ayor rotación en su negocio, haciendo de su credikiva una inversión exitosa.
texts.en:
Ledis owns a business selling merchandise. She buys clothing and natural products and meets all of her customers' orders. She sells on credit so that they can gradually pay her back every 15 days. She started this business 10 years ago, when she separated from her husband and needed to get an income of her own so she could support her family. She has two children who are currently school-aged. Her most important goal is to acquire a new house, and for that reason she works very hard in order to accomplish that.
Her biggest challenge is successfully increasing her sales, but her working capital is not enough to achieve that. Also, turnover on her accounts receivable is 17 days and the profit margin on her sales is no less than 35%. Ledis is currently requesting a Kiva loan, her first loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. With it she'll purchase clothing, vitamins and natural products which have already been ordered. These are the items that get the most turnover in her business and thus she'll make a successful investment with her Kiva loan.

loans.use: to purchase clothing, vitamins and natural products.

loans.name: Tanganyika Group

texts.fr:
Emmanuel fait partie du groupe Tanganyika  et  habite à Bujumbura. Il  a 53 ans et est marié à  Zubeda une cultivatrice. Ensemble ils ont 10 enfants âgés de 2 à 28 ans, dont 6 étudient. 

Il fait le commerce de boutique (choux, eau, haricot,…)  depuis  3 ans. 

C’est son premier crédit à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’il obtient, il va  augmenter son capital et acheter beaucoup et en grande quantité d'articles de sa boutique (haricot,sel, choux,...) à revendre  pour gagner plus. 

Dans les prochaines  années, il voudrait ouvrir des boutiques  dans d’autres coins de la province (Minago et  Gitaza)
texts.en:
Emmanuel is a member of Tanganyika Group and lives in Bujumbura. He is 53 years old and married to Zubeda, a farmer. Together, they have 10 children between the ages of 2 and 29 years old, 6 of which are currently receiving an education.

He has been running a store selling cabbages, water and beans for 3 years.

This is his first loan with Turame. With this Kiva loan, he will increase his capital and buy more and larger quantities of items for his store (beans, salt, cabbages...) which will be resold for profit.

In the coming years, he would like to open more stores elsewhere in the province (Minago and Gitaza).

loans.use: to buy larger quantities of beans, salt, cabbages and other items for his store

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe  DANAYA ont en moyenne  34 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à TOMINIAN/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des produits alimentaires.                                                                                                Après avoir remboursés correctement leurs prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe DANAYA sont à leur 9ème prêt solidaire. Hawa,  femme assise  sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter 350Kg de mil, 270Kg de maïs et 250Kg de haricot. Elle s’approvisionne sur place et dans les villages environnants. Elle effectue ses ventes sur place, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 47.000FCA sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé  et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en: The women of the Danaya group on average, are 34 years old, have four children, and all live in large traditional families in Tominian/Segou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women know one another through parentage and neighborhood ties, and run their businesses buying and selling food products. After having fully paid back all of their previous loans, the women of the Danaya group are on their ninth group loan. Hawa, the seated woman in the photo, expects to use her loan to buy 350 kilograms of millet, 270 kilograms of corn, and 250 kilograms of beans. She stocks up at home and in the surrounding villages. She makes her sales at home, to a clientele made up of women and men for cash and often for credit. She plans on making an average monthly profit of 47,000 francs CFA, which will be used for expenses related to health, with the rest to be reinvested in their businesses.

loans.use: to purchase food products like corn, millet, and beans
